ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about the many ways in which state, local, and federal US policy attempt to tackle environmental and energy problems. The syllabus of the course is very accurate and Professor Klee also pushed us to think critically about the ways in which policy can interact effectively with people, corporations, and the environment.

This was a really good survey course of many different topics in this field. Often it felt more like an interactive lecture than a seminar, but this was helpful given the amount of expertise that Klee has and the breadth of information. The course is great if you've taken a few EVST classes and have a good understanding of the main topics/focuses in the field but want to dive deeper and also learn the policy applications. You get experience writing policy memos which is a great skillset and also gives you potential writing samples to add to your portfolio.

I developed a greater awareness of the environmental policy transformations required to mitigate environmental and human health harm in the 21st century. The course examined several broad buckets of environmental problems, and discussed policy options to rectify the damage.
Different approaches to addressing energy and environmental issues in the U.S. and beyond, as well as underlying equity and justice issues that underlie them.
Learned how to write a policy memo, op-ed, about a wide variety of energy/environmental policy topics
This course provided perspective on environmental policy. It gave insightful how difficult it can be to make policy changes and how different things are connected.
extremely broad range of topics related to the environment and energy in a policy context
I gained really interesting knowledge on environmental policies and issues I had always wondered about. I think I also was able to develop my policy memo and op-ed writing skills.
I really appreciate the training received in writing policy memos. It's a useful skill.
Learned how to write a policy memo and an op Ed.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The small class size and interactive nature of Professor Klee's lecture style kept me engaged throughout the class. The class doesn't need much improvement, although I would recommend including more recent readings to the reading list, since so much has happened even in the last half-decade with regard to many of the topics discussed.

It didn't really function as a seminar, just a lecture where student discussion questions were incorporated and there were brief moments of commentary from students. I personally think this worked well for the material of the course, however it did discourage doing the readings.

This course was designed to facilitate student learning through weekly reading responses and a discussion-based class format. It was really enjoyable to hear the perspectives of all of the students in the class on these environmental dilemmas.

This course was amazing! You learn about very niche things that fit into these very large environmental problems, and think about their solutions. Great and timely readings, also assignments keep you engaged in the course!

I really don't see any weaknesses to the course. I thought the work load was very fair. I really enjoyed learning how to write policy memos and the readings each were super interesting so it it wasn't bad to complete them.

rob is actually the goat, he is so well versed in the topics, so caring for his students, offers so much of his time to help with brainstorming, gives thorough feedback on assignments, and does a great job of engaging each student on an individual basis. he is also down to earth and a real human unlike some professors.

The course was a great mix of lecture and discussion so we learned but also expressed our individual insights. The only weakness was that, on some topics (such as the electric grid), I felt like a baseline knowledge was assumed that I didn't have so it was kind of hard to follow at points.

The diversity of topics is helpful in giving us many things to think about and to pursue further. I like how conversations flow organically as well, with students sharing their points of view freely and responding to one another.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The hybrid nature of the class was welcome and engaging.

The course also met in-person for the last several weeks of the semester, subject to an in-person cap. This proceeded quite nicely, and allowed me to attend at least a few classes in-person this semester.
This is the only course I had that actually considered the fact that we are in a pandemic. The workload was timely and extensions were granted when needed, I owe Professor Klee my life for this.
Professor Klee did a great job operating on zoom and providing an in class option as well. He also was very understanding and happy to give out extensions when students needed them.
I thought the course was very engaging over zoom!
I'm not sure how helpful the hybrid style was, as we couldn't see or hear the students in the classroom as clearly.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, this is a great experience if you want to learn about environmental and energy policy from someone who was intimately involved with these topics at the state level and can offer a great perspective on all the topics.

I would highly recommend!! As a senior EVST major, I wish I would've taken it earlier but it was also nice to take it after being exposed to a lot of the content and getting the opportunity to go deeper.

I would recommend this course to another student. I really enjoyed dissecting environmental policy solutions through the lens of equity and justice. The course was organized to facilitate student learning, and made students active contributors to each class discussion.
Yes! If you get in please take it!
I would highly recommend this course to another student. Excellent experience that will change the way you look at and approach environmental and energy issues.
Absolutely!! Klee is amazing, learned a lot in this seminar
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. Professor Klee is so well informed and so much fun to listen to. Also, the course covers to many topics that it was super intriguing.
100% Rob is amazing and the course covers a strong foundation of relevant environmental issues

I recommend this to anyone, especially EVST majors because it gives you concrete knowledge on the way 'things work' that a lot of the more theoretical EVST classes don't. But it's important that non-EVST people take it too!
Yes.
Yes, if that student is more interested in economics and policy than the environmental issues themselves.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The class also had a voluntary in-person aspect where students could attend class socially distanced and in-person, which was great.
I was also able to attend a few in-person classes with Professor Klee and a small number of other students.
Included both in person seminars as well as an option to zoom in
Hyrbid in-person and zoom
In person seminar option
N/a
hybrid
There was an in person class for people who wanted to come
It was hybrid for the later half of the semester, with students being able to go to the classroom in person if they prefer.
Most classes were recorded.
